p.s: In the following it will be analysed how Obama tries to convince the audience that dreams are worth fighting for.
Obama starts off by referring to the occasion and telling the audience that he feels home to show his sympathy.
He uses a correctio (l. 2f) But the truth is... and poinspoints out that everyone shares more with each other thenthan just the place they live.
This creates a feeling of unity.
On the one hand he mentionesmentions the problem of division according to Washington and makes the audience feel responsibileresponsible by using personal pronouns.

On the other hand he uses aan anaphora (l. 7f) ... I've travelled... I haven't ... - I've been impressed... to conveyeconvey that his impressions are the opposite and that he has been impressed by the values different people share.
Additionally he uses a Parallelismparallelism (l. 12) Common hopes.American Dreams. to underline that the hopes they share are important.
This makes the audience feel worthy also as individuals.
Moreover the repetition (l. 14) ... gave him a chance ... gave them a chance makes clear that these dreams and values are reasons to hold on because thatsthat's what his Grandparentsgrandparents did.

Furthermore Obama uses another parallelism (l. 18) ... she finished her education, she followed her passion... to illustrate that these dreams drove his mother and helped her to raise him and his sister.
This makes it more relyablereliable for the audience.
The emotive language also creates a connection between Obama and the audience.
Besides the anaphora (l. 13, 17, 21) points out the impotenceimportance of the values.
To sum up Obama uses many anaphoras and parallelismparallelisms to convince the audience that the dreams are worth fighting for.
To do this he also relies to his family background.
